Her voice still had a certain musical quality, even if it wasn't quite as charming as it had been when she was hypnotizing someone. Kayva almost rejected it out of hand, but softened. She hadn't had a real conversation for years. She might occasionally tease a morsel she found alone if she was bored, but that was hardly a conversation between equals. Smiling, she looked back over her shoulder at the naga.

"Sure, why not? I'm going for a dip, why don't you tell me how you came up here. And also about," the elf gestured to the massive body, "how this happened."

Nadia grinned at the pointing fingers, then launched into her story.
"Well, nagas are usually about twelve to fifteen feet tall. The women get taller and do most of the fighting. I had a clan in the Eastern Deserts, the 200 of us ruled most of the oases running through the center. The humans mostly left us alone, but they kept spreading farther into the sands. Every few years growing up, some would become a serious trouble and there would be a fight. Our collection of warlords' skulls grew, and we'd get a year or two of rest. My first fight was pretty close to my growth. Some new tribesmen had decided they wanted our dominance gone, and took a few water spots during a sandstorm. Our own human...allies, or slaves if you want to be realistic, decided to help us. They weren't friendly with this group. Twenty of us and thirty or so of the best scouts from the men went to reclaim a well along a major road between settlements. But instead of the 75 barbarians we were supposed to meet we found close to 180 warriors. They were a fresh group, but still numbers were a lot.

It was still a wonderful fight," Nadia said, eyes focusing on something far away and long ago. "We waited for a sandstorm to brew up, it didn't take long. Then we stormed the camp. At least twenty died before they knew what was happening. And then it was just hand to hand. I had no idea how any of my brothers or sisters were doing. I just charged through. We were armed with scimitars, good for slashing while running. These humans had little experience in fighting, and seeing something twice their size moving so fast was enough to make most of them break. It was barely even a fight at that point. I fell off a dune, kicked by one of the camp's horses, and landed in five of them. I remember the glee on their faces, the triumph when one swung his sword down at me. I thought I was dead. But the weapon just bounced off my breastplate, barely leaving a scratch. Then it was my turn to laugh. I decapitated two instantly. Another was a decent swordsman, I had to fight his two friends off with my tail while trying to keep this one from gutting me. I finally managed to knock his sword away and cracked his neck. At this point the other two had run. I managed to skewer one with the scimitar. The other I chased down, and caught him in my coils. It was such a rush, having that much power over something alive! I was cruel, but don't regret it. If I had asked, he probably would have thanked me when I finally crushed the breath from his lungs. I felt like a goddess. Five dead, all by my hand in minutes.

But then the storm died down. Everyone was dead. There was no one left. Well, there was one. A human the equivalent my age from one of our subject villages. He was wary of me, and not without cause. I was scared he would go for me the minute my back turned. But we both saw there was no point. Our first job was to survive. The troops hadn't brought much water, as we thought we'd have a secure well an hour after the start of battle. But the first thing the invaders did was poison the water, turning it a filmy green. Our own home was a three day walk. So we started walking. And we walked. For three days. We both weakened, him first. Humans are not an animal well suited to heat. I made the mistake of trying to carry him the last day. All it did was wear me down. I got within ten miles of the village, I could practically see the sand-colored tents and hear the voices of my people. But I collapsed, this human boy clutched against me. I thought we would both die. Then one hand came to rest on his neck, almost by accident. I could feel his heartbeat, and liters of liquid rushing through him. He knew as soon as I did what was going to happen. At full strength he may have been able to fight back. But I just lifted him and tore out his throat. The first swallow of food in days, his flesh was delicious. And rivers of blood, salty, refreshing blood, poured down my throat. When he was dry I left the body in the sand and trekked home. My conscience twinged remembering what I did! but I was alive and that mattered more to me at that moment.

Unfortunately, I had killed the son of our community's sorcerer. We are not good at magic. Humans can be, not as good as elves, but they are passable. He saw me come crawling back, drenched in blood. It must have called to him, he greeted me at the edge of town with the rest of the village. But he almost instantly gave a howl of anguish and charged me. Seymour was curious what would happen when one of his pieces were captured. ‘I’d better find out now with a pawn rather than later with a more powerful piece.’ He thought before ordering the pawn he moved last turn forward again. When Kayva took the pawn and replaced it with her own, she didn’t set it to the side as Seymour expected. Instead she dropped the human chess piece into her mouth and swallowed it.

“Bishop left three, and that’s checkmate.” Seymour declared after several strenuous hours, or at least what seemed like hours, of game play. Kayva blinked in surprise before her eyes darted around the board, wildly searching for a move to make.

“Congratulations Seymour, that’s the first time in ages anyone has beaten me at chess.” Kayva finally admitted as the board disappeared .

“It’s not hard to see why.” Seymour said, “Well with that over, I suppose it’s one to your third challenge.”

Kayva smiled, “Quite right. Your third challenge is…”
1321111.title: Seymour wins

“Your third challenge is to make your way through this temple, “Kayva said as stone walls lined with moss and other plant growth rose around them, “and retrieve the gem hidden within. Now like all ancient temples with treasure, this one has deadly traps. These ones won’t actually kill or hurt you, but if you receive a ‘fatal injury’ you’ll ‘die’ and lose the challenge. If you can make it past the traps and the temple guardian, and then capture the gem, you win the challenge and your freedom. Good luck.” She said before disappearing.

Seymour set off through the temple, all the while narrowly avoiding poisonous darts, spike pits, and once a massive boulder that almost crushed him. He encountered many puzzles along the way; such as doors that would only open if the colored squares that decorated them were arranged in the right pattern, and a floor tiled with stones with elfin runes and the only safe way across was to step on the stones that spelled Kayva’s name.
After evading several more traps and solving numerous puzzles Seymour made it to a large room. At the back he saw an altar with a large purple gem. His first instinct was to rush for the gem, but he remembered what Kayva said about a temple guardian. Instead he carefully stepped into the enormous room.

As Seymour entered the stone door closed behind him. There was a moment of eerie silence before a huge foot came zooming down at him. Seymour managed to leap out of the way in time before hearing a familiar voice.

“Surprise!” Kayva giggled.

“So you’re the temple guardian.” Seymour said as he stood up again.

“Hehe, yep. I always enjoy being part of the action.” Kayva said merrily as she moved to stand between Seymour and the altar. “Now it’s time to see if you can succeed in you quest.”
13211112.title: A daring adventure

132111122.content:
Seymour was able to use his speed and diminutive, compared to Kayva’s, size to his advantage. He ran through a series of sudden changes in direction and reverses to confuse and disorient Kayva. In the end it worked all too well. Seymour’s movements made Kayva dizzy and he was now stumbling around as though she were drunk.

Seymour walked over towards the altar, but hadn’t expected Kayva to lose her balance they way she did. The last thing he saw was a dark shadow before something heavy and somewhat soft came down on him.


Kayva moaned as she realized that she was sitting down now. It took a moment for her to realize that the temple scene was gone and that she was sitting on something. She stood up and saw that she’d been sitting on Seymour. “Oops.” She said as she blushed, “Good thing this is a dream huh?”

“Yeah, if this was real I’d probably be dead right now.” Seymour said with a feeble laugh.

“True, and you do know what that means? It means you lost the challenge.” Kayva said sounding quite pleased.
“Oh yeah…” Seymour said with dread.

“Don’t worry just yet Seymour. I give out little consolation prizes to those that impress me.” Kayva said comfortingly.

“Consolation prizes?” Seymour asked.

“That’s right. For example, if you lost the second challenge, I would have allowed you to sleep through me eating and digesting you. Losing the third challenge earns you that plus you get a free request. This request can be almost anything. Note the ‘almost’. I’m certainly not going to allow you to go free after all this trouble.” Kayva replied. “So, what is your request?”

She went home that evening, after saving a pair of children from a bear and getting some fruit for her meal. Her older, but obviously shorter, brother Varon was outside in his forge, working a piece of metal over hot coals when Kayva arrived. “Good evening Varon.” Kayva said as she approached. “Evening sister.” Varon replied as he quenched the glowing metal, “Tamir and Yara told me about how you saved their children. I thought the bears had already left for the season. Good thing you were around.”

“Yes, I suppose it was.” Kayva sighed as she carefully sat down next to the forge. “Something wrong Kayva?” Varon asked as he came outside, gazing up at his sister. “Well, it isn’t something drastically important. But seeing Tamir and Yara overcome with relief that the kids were safe, reminded me that… having a child of my own is no longer available; ever since that day where I grew to this size. My old master may have been able to find a way, but she disappeared for over a year right after the accident and died just after she returned.” Kayva replied, wiping a tear from her eye.

“Well, she never told anyone why she left for so long. She may have gone off looking for a way to change you back or if there were others that had your same accident.” Varon suggested. Kayva pondered on this for a moment, her old master was a caring elf particularly when it came to her student. “You may be right. There is no reason for us to wait, lets go and see what might be at her place.” Kayva said. “Now?” Varon asked as Kayva lowered her hand. “Yes, now. Come on Varon, I’m scarier than anything in these woods since the dragons went north for the summer.” Kayva said before she grabbed and lifted her brother, rather unceremoniously. “Kayva! You know I hate it when you do that!” Varon shouted.
132111222.title: With the Elves

“Oh my, the place seems to have fallen into disrepair.” Kayva exclaimed when they arrived at the hollowed tree her old master used to live in. Several branches were bare of leaves despite the season, moss had grown over much of the tree, and the beds of once beautiful flowers that lined the base of the tree were brown and dry. “No one’s lived here for years, Kayva. You know what legends say about those like her with so much magical power after they die.” Varon said as his sister lowered him to the ground.

“If there’s anything that could give us a clue as to how to bring you back to normal size, or otherwise, it would be inside. Where should I look?” Varon asked as he stood by the front door, ready to enter. “My master kept her private and most secret belongings in her bedroom; she may even have had a secret compartment there.” Kayva suggested. Varon nodded before entering the house, mentally preparing for just about anything.

The interior of the tree was surprisingly clean; Varon ventured a guess that the magic of the area kept dust from settling. He made his way to the bedroom, taking care not to disturb the various magical items stored in what where to him awkward places. After he entered the bedroom he kept along the walls, gently knocking on the wood and listening for a hollow space behind them.
1321112222.title: Her master’s home

13211122222.content:
“It’s not in the walls young one.” A faintly echoing voice said. Varon nearly screamed in shock by the sudden break of the silence. He turned and saw an elf woman, pale and semi-transparent, a ghost. “You’re Kayva’s old teacher, Jassami, aren’t you?” Varon cautiously guessed. “And you must be Kayva’s brother; she told me much about you while I was alive.” Jassami said as she nodded.

“As I said, what you’re looking for isn’t in the walls. It is beneath us, under the floor. The door is hidden beneath my bed.” Jassami said before her ghost vanished. It took Varon a moment to get his legs to work again. He carefully moved the bed from its position and found the trapdoor Jassami’s ghost spoke of. He pulled on the iron ring and the door opened, revealing a small indent in the wood of the tree. In it was a leather-bound book, a journal most likely. Varon carefully lifted the book from its hiding place then returned the bed to its original position.

Kayva sat outside, patiently waiting for her brother. “What did you find?” she asked eagerly when he finally emerged from the tree house. “I found this,” Varon answered holding out the book, “It may be your master’s journal. If so, it may hold the reason she ventured away after the accident, and how we can set your life in the direction you want to go.” “I know where I want my life to go: I want to have a child; whether by returning to my original stature or by finding others with this affliction, or what have you.” Kayva said. “Well then, let’s see what we’ve got in here.” Varon said before opening the book.

“It is a journal, everything in here was written by Jassami’s own hand,” Varon said as he scanned through the pages of the book, “This might be something, this entry is from the day after your accident. In many ways it pains me to write today, after what happened to my young apprentice Kayva. I had no idea that my experiment would go so askew. Now she stands nearly as tall as the trees, naked as the day she was born. I know not why the gods chose for this event to occur, but I owe it to my apprentice to at the very least find a way to reverse my mistake or a way to ease her transition to a new life. I set out for my quest at dawn, I will return once I’ve found the secret I seek.”

“She returned so she must have found something. What secret did she find?” Kayva asked

132111222222.title: Beyond reversal

Varon looked at the journal, browsing the entries, “Let’s see… This looks like it might be something. It took some time before I was able to find a way to possibly help Kayva become a mother in her new state of being. I was able to collect a favor from a dragon friend of mine. She called in a favor from a dragon for me, wow… Well, anyway, try to read the ancient language part.”

As Varon slowly read the words written in the strange language Kayva translated the words in her mind. It was soon clear that, as her master said, it was indeed a sensitive subject. The next evening Kayva used her Dreamweaving powers to probe the minds of the female elves in the nearby village, silently searching for the best to help her. Eventually she decided on…

I doubt it. I may as well be living in the middle of the forest, no one notices me. Why because I’m too scared to do anything worth noticing. But I can thank my father for that…”

To what do I owe the honor of your summons?” Savina said gazing up in awe at the giantess.

No matter what Kayva said she was still amazed, Kayva was a legend amongst the elves and she was right here speaking to her, a loner that barely anyone knew was alive. “Well, I was using my Dreamweaving magic some time ago, and I saw some of your memories.” Kayva said. Savina felt disappointment settling in; she didn’t want anyone’s pity. “Anyway, that’s what brought me to you. I wanted to ask of you… wait, um… Would you be, averse to… becoming my daughter?” Kayva asked, blushing with embarrassment.

I’m an adult among our people, so I can’t be adopted. Not that anyone would probably notice or care.” Savina said, turning away to hide her shame. “I didn’t mean like that Savina.” Kayva said quietly. 151112.content:
Leaves rustling about her waist, Kayva pressed through the great woods, her bare torso rising above the treetops. She had never bothered to measure herself exactly; but knew well enough that an adult human was about as tall as her longest finger. Certainly at first the experience had been enthralling; she had felt empowered, and excited to use that power to help people.

But then they had become afraid; her master unable to turn her back. Despite all assurances of her good intentions, Kayva had eventually found it best to just leave. She had been wandering the great forest for years now, completely alone except for in her dreams. Tonight did not look like it would be any different, she figured with a defeated sigh; her long tapered ears drooping down from where they protruded from her unkempt mane of fiery red hair.

Trodding onward she looked up to spot the massive tree growing in the crook of the hills she approached, a smile finally gracing her lips as her angular green eyes took it in; making her feel for a moment almost normal. The positively titanic dragon trees were rare even in the all but endless great wood; but Kayva knew by heart where many of them were. They were one of few things large enough for a dragon to roost in; and large enough to grow fruit worth their time, and by extension, for Kayva.

Strolling up to the tree with a saunter in her step she reached up to grab one of the, to her, low hanging fruit; an ovoid, ribbed thing with a skin of mottled gold. Swallowing the saliva that had built up in anticipation of her first good meal in a week, Kayva opened her mouth to take a bite when the crunch she had been expecting preceded her doing so.

Blinking she lowered her hand and glanced about, hearing what sounded like chewing from the far side of the tree. Wonderful, she thought to herself, another godsforsaken dragon. She rarely bumped into them; since they were oft out hunting at night, and even then most were amicable, but some had decided to fight her over "their" fruit, and the scarred clawmark down her freckled cheek was proof enough that they were trouble even for her.

Kayva, however, was not about to be scared away from a meal. Setting the fruit down and clenching her fists, she rounded the tree, ready to smack the stupid lizard square in the nose, but stopped with a yelp of alarm at what she found instead.

The man leaning up against the tree likewise jumped, dropping the fruit he was holding as he beheld the woman accosting him. "W-whoa, what..." He exclaimed, forcing his back up against the tree.

Kayva's hands fell to her side as she stepped back, dumfounded, "uh-uhmm..." was all she could manage. She stared at him stupidly; taking in a thin, athletic frame; not entirely well hid by the silken green trousers and open-fronted vest he wore, baring his chest and abs.

"E-eye's up here miss," he joked, moving his own from the shapely, freckled, totally naked woman that had appeared so suddenly.

Looking up, the elfess' gaze traced across his pointy chin and it's small patch of golden hairs, past his lips and nose and finally met his blue eyed gaze, her next breath heavy as an electric tingle ran up her spine.

His own ears giving an excited flick, the male elf runs a hand through his short shock of golden hair and smiles more naturally, "Umm...this is unexpected. U-umm, my name is Telthis, umm, miss...?"

"I err, ah, umm, Kayva!" She finally managed to reply, shaking her head, suddenly so very conscious of her frazzled hair and its cargo of leaves and broken twigs, of her scar and her nudity, "M-my name is Kayva...I...you're...big, like me."

"Hah, an astute observation, Kayva," the man replied, "I umm...it looks like you've been this way longer than me...are you...stuck?"

"O-of course I am! My master tried this stupid spell and...I've been wandering the woods scaring off everyone for..." She gave a small whimper, "...too long, far too long."

"O-oh hey, now, it's alright..." Telthis responded with a start, eyes full of worry as he reached out a hand, cupping her chin and running a thumb gently across her scar, tilting her head back a little to meet her gaze; "...I..." He began, but Kayva interrupted him.
151112.title: Elf

1511121.content:
Telthis gave a surprised "oof!" as Kayva flung herself forward, teary eyed as she grabbed onto him and buried her face in his chest. After a moment of seeing her hold tight and whimper, the male elf lowers his own arms to wrap about her waist and settles his chin atop her head.

"H-hey now, I don't know what you've been through but everything is going to be fine," he says, raising a hand to absently begun plucking tree branches from her hair, "You've been through a lot huh?"

She nods silently, sniffling and taking a deep breath to try and calm herself; this couldn't be making the best first impression but still...

"I-I haven't been able to just...touch another person in..." She shakes her head, sighing and looking back up to him, still a little misty eyed.

He offered a thin smile back and slowly began to crouch down, back against the tree. Kayva gave a curious look and flick of her ears, but he drew her down with him, until hey were both sitting at the base of the trunk, Kayva half in his lap and still leaned against him for support.

"Why don't you tell me your story..." Telthis offered, putting a comforting arm around her.

Nodding, Kayva started from the beggining; her apprenticeship, the spell gone awry, the terror it had caused her home town. She paused awkwardly and fumbled words; trying to remember how to speak quite right outside of her own head, but in the end managed. Telthis listened intently to her story, his arms slowly tightening protectively around her as she related her ordeal; surviving in a wilderness not really up to the task of supporting her, naked and alone.

"That's some tale," He says softly as she finishes, "You're something else to tough it out so long, I'm impressed."

"T-thanks," she said with a blush, turning her head slightly away; trying to keep a handle on herself but not sure how well she was succeeding. He was the first man she'd seen in years, and his attractiveness, she was sure, was not simply a play of the light or her company-starved mind.
